did.unittitle: Board of Trustees records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: George Washington University. Board of Trustees

did.abstract: Collection include meeting minutes (original and microfilm), correspondence, charters and by-laws, committee files, and congressional documents relating to the University.

odd.head: Collection note
odd.p: Partial index to the minutes of the Board are kept with second copy of microfilm. Please see staff for assistance.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials acquired through transfers from the Board of Trustees.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The management, direction, and government of George Washington University is vested in a Board of Trustees. Pursuant to the by-laws of the University, the Board consists of the President as an ex officio member, three alumni or alumnae members elected to the Board at each annual meeting for terms of three years; with one alumni Trustee being a "recent graduate" who serves for one term of three years and two Alumni Trustees serving for a maximum of two terms of three years; and the balance of not less than thirty nor more than forty-five persons, each elected to the Board for three year terms. Trustees elected after January 1, 1992 may not serve more than three consecutive terms without stepping down for a minimum of one year, after which they are eligible for reelection. Persons are qualified to serve as Trustees regardless of race, color, creed, sex, national origin, or place of residence. With the exception of the President, no person who is an officer, professor, lecturer, teacher, tutor, student or employee of the University, or is 75 years of age or older, is eligible to serve as a Trustee. The Executive Committee is responsible for taking all actions and exercising all powers of the Board, except that it may not elect Trustees, amend the by-laws or approve the merger of any other corporation with the University. The Executive Committee consists of the Chairman of the Board, as chairman, the President, and at least eight Trustees appointed by the chairman for a one year term.

The University operates under a charter granted by an Act of Congress on February 9, 1821 to the Columbian College in the District of Columbia. In 1873, the name was changed to Columbian University and in 1904 to The George Washington University.

From 1872 to 1900 the Board of Trustees was known as the Board of Overseers. The Board approves curriculum, tuition, faculty hires, etc. The Board appoints various committees which are empowered to act between meetings of the full Board. These include the Executive, Academic Affairs, Financial Affairs, Audit, Buildings and Grounds, Compensation, Medical Center, Development, Student and Alumni Affairs, Trusteeship, External Affairs, Investments, and University Trusteeship Committees.

Former prominent members represented in this collection include: Luther Rice, John Quincy Adams, Peter Force, Joseph Henry, William Corcoran, Amos Kendall, Edward Gallaudet, Alexander Graham Bell, Gilbert Grosvenor, Ulysses S. Grant III, and J. Edgar Hoover.
N.B. This history note was written in 2005

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection include meeting minutes (original and microfilm), correspondence, charters and by-laws, committee files, and congressional documents relating to the University. These materials range in date from 1821 to 2003 and includes early correspondence going back to the 1820's, biographical information on Trustees, and the physical development of the University and evolution of schools and departments. Elmer Kayser's book on the history of the University, "Bricks Without Straw" was based on information found in the Board of Trustees records. The material was transferred to the University Archives by the Board of Trustees and the University Historian.

Former prominent members represented in this collection include: Luther Rice, John Quincy Adams, Peter Force, Joseph Henry, William Corcoran, Amos Kendall, Edward Gallaudet, Alexander Graham Bell, Gilbert Grosvenor, Ulysses S. Grant III, and J. Edgar Hoover.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: Papers, Microfilm, George Washington University's annual fund, George Washington University's charter, Committees, Congressional documents, Faculty, and Records.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
accessrestrict.p: Series 1, 2, and 5 are closed to research for 50 years from date of record creation.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Board of Trustees records, University Archives, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is a collection of the meeting minutes and correspondence of the following Board of Trustees' committees: educational policy, alumni relations, building lands, endowment funds, executive committee, finance, university hospital, personnel, and libraries. They range in date from 1911 to 1960.

Committee on Educational Policy--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "The committee voted to recommend to the Board the proposals concerning the merger of the Junior College with Columbian College, to be effective Sept. 1, 1961,. The new name for the College will be the Columbian College of Arts and Sciences. The meeting adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on Educational Policy--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Approval of recommendation that the Juris Doctor Degree be discontinued as a first degree of law effecive with respect to students entering the Law School in the 1961-62 academic year. Approval of "A Future Educational Policy for the School of Medicine" Approval of change in name and organization of the School of Government. The Committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on Educational Policy--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "The Committee on Educational Policy by correspondence, approved the recommendation that the regulations regarding the 21 tuition scholarships for full-time students in the Law School be amended, so that any scholarships that are open due: 1) to lack of qualified applicants 2) to resignations prior to entry into Law School 3) to resignations during residence in Law School, or 4) to failure to meet scholarship requirements shall be available to students with "B" averages who have completed one or two years of work."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Negotiations under way for purchase of Lot 17, Sq. 119 (1912 Pa. Ave.). The Committee authorized an offer of $42,000 for this property. (If necessary $45,000) Committee advised of offers to sell 1916 G Street (Lot E, Sq. 120) to the University for $25,000. The Committee took no action regarding this property. The Committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on Building Lands--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Report of real estate purchases made since Sept. 1, 1959 under authority granted by Board on Oct 8, 1959. Authority granted to the Committee by the Board Oct 8, 1959, was amended to permit purchases within a total expenditure of $600,000 (instead of $400,000). It was further provided that the limitation of $600,000 be increased by purchase price of Liberty Baptist Church property if the property is authorized by the Board. Liberty Baptist Church property was considered. Approval of recommendation to the Board that property be purchased at a price of $180,000. Approval of purchase of property at 1916 H St. N.W. for $20,000 and properties at 733 245h St. N.W. and the rear of 2312 H St. N.W. for a combined price off $15,000. The committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on Building Lands--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Authorization for purchase of 2104-6-8-10 Pennsylvania Avenue at total cost of $190,000. (Sq. 75-Lots 28, 27, 839, 838) Ratification of authorizations of Chmn Lawson and Acting Pres. Colclough to purchase the following properties: 2104 Eye St. (Sq. 77 - Lot 28); 600 and 612 22nd St. (Sq. 57 - Lots 49 &43) 913 22nd St. (Sq. 75 - Lot 817) Rear of 919 22nd St. (Sq. 75 - Lot 843). Treasurer authorized to pay no more than $12,000 for purchase of 729 22nd St. (Sq. 79 - Lot 33). Approval of recommendation that authority granted B & L Committee at Board Mtg. Oct 8, 1959, be amended to include the following provision: that the President of the Univ., with the concurrence of the Chmn. of the Comm., be authorized to make purchases of property for $25,000 or less, within the limitations. Treasurer was requested to secure an appraisal of 813-17-21 23rd St. (Sq. 55, Lots 812, 815, 843). Treasurer reported about a piece of property in Law Center Square. The owner recently died; the administrator of his estate said that the Univ. will be given first consideration if property becomes available for sale."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on Folder "Approval of recommendation that during 1956-60 fiscal year the Committee on B & L authorized to purchase properties within expenditure of $400,000 for the fiscal year in certain squares. Approval of recommendation that during 1956-60 fiscal the Finance Committee be authorized to mortgage University income-producing properties to the extent of $400,000 to carry out the property acquisition to program recommended by the Buildings and Lands Committee. See Finance Committee folder for signed minutes."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on Folder "Under authority granted by Board the following properties were purchased: Square 40, Lot 825; Square 77, Lot 829; Square 77, Lot 828. The Committee authorized Treasurer to purchase Square 57, Lot 27 at a price not to exceed $14,500 from the Pairo Fund; The Committee authorized Treasurer to purchase Square 55, Lot B at $13,000 from general surplus funds; The Committee approved the purchase of Square 119, Lot 805 at $45,000; The Committee approved the purchase of Square 77, Lot 33 at $17,500; The Committee authorized the Treasurer to purchase Square 75, Lot 33 at $12,000; The Committee authorized the Treasurer to purchase Square 57, Lot 834 at $12,500 from Pairo Fund; Purchases in Square 57 can be cared for from Pairo Fund, purchases in Squares 40 and 75 from Surplus Hospital Funds, and remaining purchases from surplus in General University Funds."

did.unittitle: Committee on Building Lands--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.p: Text on Folder "Recommendation that resolution authorizing the execution of a loan agreement with the United States of America for the financing of the purchase and remodeling of Dolly Madison and John Quincy Adams Halls be presented to the Board; Recommendation that resolution be issued to the Riggs National Bank for the purpose of borrowing be presented to the Board. A rough estimate of the cost of remodeling these apartments is $300,000 each. It was agreed these estimates were high; President Marvin suggested the application for funds be increased to make available $1,500,000. The Committee asked that a statement be prepared for presentation to the Board."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Chairman Fleming withdrew his name from consideration for the Chairmanship of the Board. Letter from Acting President Colclough to Chairman Fleming considered. Resolution to honor Chairman Fleming approved by the Committees. Trustee Ellison was named as nominee for office of the Chairman; Trustee E.K. Morris and Trustee Godfrey Munter were named to fill offices of Secretary and Assistant Secretary; it was suggested that Trustee Strong be asked if he would allow his name to be recommended to the Board for the office of Vice Chairman. Acting President Colclough advised the Committees that a new HUMRRO contract had been concluded and a contract signed at a fixed fee of $220,000. The members of the Special Committee to Consider the Future Leadership of the University agreed to meet for luncheon on May 14, 1959."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Report by Mr. Van Devanter concerning the University Investment Portfolio. Approval of extension of real estate loan held by Riggs National Bank in the amount of $350,000, secured by the deed of trust on Old Hospital and Medical School properties, for five year at 51/2%. Approval of resolution to substitute the name of H.J. Cantini for that of John A. McLaughlin (former resolution adopted Oct. 13, 1955). Approval or recommendation to amend Section 9 of Chapter 5 of the By-Laws concerning "access to the saftey deposit box" to note change in Treasurer's title and to provide access to the box when a member of the Finance Committee is not available. The Finance Committtee recommended that authority granted by Board to the Buildings and Lands Committee be increased to $800,000; That the authority granted to Finance Committee on Ovtober 8, 1959 be amended so the Committee can mortgage property to the extent of $800,000 to carry out property acquisition program of the Committee on Buildings and Lands. Approval of temporary transfer of funds ($200,000) from Current Funds Surplus-Appropriated for Hospital" to "Current Funds - Unappropriated". Approval of Auditor's certificate. The committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on Financial and Legal Affairs--meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Discussion of securities received from the DeKnight Estate; decision to sell all bond issues except $2,000 par value Wash. Gas Light Co., to retain the preferred stock issue, the 12 common stock issues and 5 real estate note issues and to add the retained investments to the Consolidated Endowment Funds at their market value on date of receipt from the American Security & Trust Co. Committee suggested that Mr. Van Devanter review all the preferred stock holdings of the University in the light of present market conditions. The Committee thought its statement of April 24, 1957, establishing a limitation of $50,000 for investment of endowment funds in any individual company should be reviewed and a new basis for a desirable limit be established. Pending adoption of a new basis, it was agreed that Investment Counsel could bring to Committee recommendations for purchase of more than $50,000 in one company if the investment seemed to merit the purchase of such an amount."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "It was recommended that the Auditor's Report be presented to the Board for acceptance. It was voted to defer making any recommendation to the Board in reference to appointment of auditors for next fiscal year until the May Board Mtg. Committee voted to present statement of Comparative Financial Highlights to the Board at its next meeting. Committee approved tuition fees, special fees and dormitory charges to be effective September 1, 1958. Approval of proposed budget for1958-59 and it was recommended the budget be presented to the Board for adoption. The Committee adourned [adjourned] at 3:00 o'clock."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Committee authorized investment of the Ford Foundation Grants and maturing U.S. Treasury Bills, in 90 Day Bills on a "roll over" basis until longer acceptable investments at better yields are available. Reinvestment to be in a new bond issues. Presentation of Comparative Summary of Portfolio of Endowment Funds to be presented to the Board semi-annually. Recommendation concerning limitation on investment in common stock. To ask Board to rescind action of March 11, 1937, and authorize investment in common stocks not to exceed 45% of the book value. One more member to be added to the Finance Committee. Chairman of the Committee and President to recommend person. Investment in one company to be limited to $50,000, unless Investment Counsel recommends otherwise."

did.unittitle: Committee on Financial and Legal Affairs

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "The following recommendation were approved: 1. Employment of Mr. Winslow B. Van Devanter as Investment Counselor effective April 1, 1956, subject to 30 days cancellation notice - replacing Lionel D. Edie & Co., Inc. 2. Purchase of 400 shares General American Transportation Corp. stock. 3. Employment of Price Waterhouse & Co. as auditors, effective at beginning of current fiscal year - replacing R.G. Rankin & Co. 4. Authorization to utilize excess cash funds for investment in U.S. Treasury Bills or Govt. maturities of less than one year, not to exceed $300,000. 5. Authorization to purchase or sell fractional shares issued on equities held in University portfolio. 6. Authorization to sell securities given to Univ. for expendable purposes in near future - up to $2,000 market value with the approval of one member of the Committee; if greater value, approval of a majority of the Committee is required. 7. Authorization to exchange short term Governments on rollovers. To present, with advice of legal counsel, a resolution to the Board covering distribution of income of Consolidated Endowment Funds, effective 9/1/55, on the basis of shares established for each participating fund rather than book value. Consideration of changes in Chapter V, Section 9 of the By-Laws; approved change in terminology of Comptroller to Treasurer and Asst. Comptroller to Asst. Treasurer, but decided against any change in the policy of who might have access to the securities."

did.unittitle: Committee on Personnel--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "The Committee reviewed the personnel changes recommended by the appropriate officers and deans, and the Acting President, and voted to recommend their favorable consideration by the Board of Trustees. The Committee thought it a good idea to invite a particular Dean from time to time to discuss before the Board specific matters falling under his cognizance which the Board had under consideration. Acting President Colclough said he would take the matter up with Chairman Fleming. Discussion of action taken by Board on February 8, 1934: "It was voted that after the close of the present fiscal year the University would not employ two members of the same family." At present there are 3 cases of married couples contributing their services to the University without compensation. The Committee voted to recommend to the Board that the action taken on February 8, 1934, be interpreted as not barring the employment of two members of the same family both of whom contribute their services to the University without compensation."

did.unittitle: Committee on Personnel--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "The committee reviewed the personnel changes recommended by the appropriate officers and deans, and the President, and voted to recommend their favorable consideration by the Board of Trustees. Approval of President's recommendation to offer Mr. Robert Faris a five-year contract with the understanding that during that period Mr. Faris would have the opportunity to develop himself that he might merit academic status and eventually tenure. Discussion of the continuation of George Wythe, Professorial Lecturer in Economics, during spring term although he would normally retire in February because of age. The committee felt that recommendations for the continuation of part-time members of the staff beyond the normal retirement age should be kept to an absolute minimum. The committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Approval of recommendation for addition of a residency in the Dept. of Surgery in the field of plastic surgery to be used in the Hospital and Cancer Clinic; President Marvin suggested a study be made of the internships and residencies re number of positions and compensation; Report on Courtesy Allowance Policy was represented. It will be considered at a later meeting after review by the Treasurer; Approval of recommendation establishing Intensive Care Unit for critically ill post-operative patients. The meeting adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Discussion of the Hospital policy in reference to discounts. A complete statement of the present discount policy was requested by the Committee; Approval of an increase in a month;y beginning salary from $270 to $290 for graduate nurses; Discussion of 2 proposals for expanding facilities of Medical Center: the building of new wing on the Hospital for which the University had received $200,000 from the Ford Foundation, the purchase of the Keystone Apartments. No recommendation was made. President Marvin said the decision should be made by the Board; Treasurer Herzog was asked to find out if the Keystone is still available and to secure an estimate of the cost and method of financing the purchase and also secure data on cost of remodeling part of the building for new uses; The Committee adjourned."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Approval by the Committee of the following: A Resident in Neurology effective July 1, 1958; Purchase of new bedside tables for the hospital at cost of $18,000; Refinishing of hospital furniture in patients' rooms. This is not to exceed $10,000 for first year. Contract with Group Hospitalization, Inc.; Relationship between the George Washington University Cancer Clinic and the Hospital discussed. It was the feeling of the Committee the Hospital and clinic should be brought as closely together as possible in administration; The Committee adjourned at 2:20 o'clock."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Executive Committee of the Hospital Staff met with the Committee to consider plans for making application for the Ford Foundation grant of $226,500: Discussion about need for a new medical school building; Need for expansion of the Hospital - laboratories, Pediatrics, etc.; 4-story addition to the Hospital vs. a smaller addition for the present; Competition with Children's Hospital if Dept. of Pediatrics is established; Recommendations to be made to the Board of Trustees regarding use of the funds, with a 250,000 cubic foot addition at a cost of not more than $500,000."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on Folder "Approval for Executive Committee of Hospital to be invited to meet with the Board Committee from time to time; Discussion concerning Ford Foundation Grant Application; Approval of expansion of service in Pathology to include Clinical Pathologist. (Would replace Dr. Choisse on Medical School staff); Proposal to study possibility of affiliation with Children's Hospital for Pediatric Service; Passed over expansion of Neurosurgery and Psychiatry; Number of interns and residents not to be increased unless more staff beds could be provided; Report of American Hospital Assn. and Assn. of American Medical Schools relative to perquisites to be obtained; Reopening of the union contract and possible wage increases. Referred to Committee on Bldgs. and Lands: Additional wing for expanded work in Pathology and other laboratories, office space for professional staff and Business Offices; Problem of space for lockers, records, and laundry; Possibility of building parking ramp in Square 55. Discussion of Out Patient Dept. To see if Mellon gift precludes transfer out of the Hospital building; Air conditioning - possibility of use of room units; Iowa Court Decision re revenues from laboratories and ex-ray service; Discussion of Medical Director of the Hospital upon the retirement of Dean Bloedorn; Working capital of Hospital. Study to be made to see how other hospitals stand in accounts receivable; Discussion of building funds under Law221 and Hill-Burton Act."

did.unittitle: Committee on the University Hospital--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note

'54; Remodeling of second floor of Out Patient Department. Approved. Report on Hospital salaries to see if space should be provided; Refurnishing 5 private rooms. Approved; Additional Resident in Surgery approved; Additional Junior Resident in Obstetrics approved; Rehabilitation program discussed; Purchase of diagnostic X-Ray Unit and Rotational attachment for Picker Therapy machine for Dept. of Radiology; Report on all special services in Hospital asked for; Air conditioning discussed."

did.unittitle: Committee on Legal Affairs--correspondence and meeting minutes

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text on folder "Discussion of an offer of $200 for scholarship aid for Negro students. It was felt in light of social trends any scholarship accepted should not carry racial restrictions. The University has 2 scholarships restricted to the white race; the committee felt hereafter it wold not be desirable to accept scholarships with racial restrictions; however, no attempt should be made to alter the terms of scholarships previously accepted. The above scholarship will be offered without restrictions; approval of trustees' fees on portion of testamentary trust in the Clarence W. DeKnight Estate (3% by American Security and Trust Company and 3% by Mr. Frank Nesibitt). The committee adjourned."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is a collection of Congressional documents and related materials regarding The George Washington University and its predecessors. They range in date from 1826 to 1977.
